Mrs. Bennet.Action: Encourages Mr. Bennet to visit Mr. Bingley for the sake of their daughters' prospects.
Disagrees with Mr. Bennet’s preference for Lizzy over their other daughters.
Views a wealthy single man as a potential husband for her daughters solely based on his fortune.
Resentfully speaks about Mrs. Long being selfish.
Scolds her daughter Kitty for coughing.
Expresses bitterness and exaggeration regarding Mr. Darcy's perceived rudeness.
Expresses distress over Mr. Bingley's lack of interest in settling down at Netherfield.
Speaks negatively of Miss Lucas's attractiveness compared to her daughter Jane.
Speaks civilly to Miss Lucas despite her strong opinions.
Declares she would take away a bottle of wine from a young Lucas for drinking too much.
Shows eagerness for Mr. Bingley’s affections despite Jane's discomfort
Expresses a desire for her daughters to marry rich men with high social status.
Had no wish of Jane recovering immediately as her restoration to health would probably remove her from Netherfield.
Repeated her thanks to Mr. Bingley for his kindness to Jane.
Expresses satisfaction that Jane will stay at Netherfield longer.
Claims Sir William is the epitome of good breeding.
Insists her daughters are brought up differently, implying superiority.
Refused to send the carriage early.
Welcomed them home uncordially and wondered at their coming.
Refuses to send carriage earlier than planned and hopes Mr. Bingley and his sister will pressure her daughters to stay longer.
Expresses readiness to receive Mr. Collins with composure despite initial ill-will.
Responds readily to Mr. Collins' compliments and wishes her daughters well in marriage.
Accepts Mr. Collins' apology and declares herself not offended.
Complains about the entail favouring Mr. Collins over her daughters.
Speaks politely about Lady Catherine and shows interest in her family.
Notes Miss de Bourgh's fortunate situation.
Persuades Mr. Collins to consider marrying Elizabeth instead of Jane.
Finds Mr. Collins and a potential marriage to her daughters acceptable when previously indifferent
Feels flattered by receiving the ball invitation personally from Mr. Bingley.
Enumerates the advantages of Jane's potential marriage to Bingley, emphasizing wealth and proximity.
Insists Elizabeth stay to hear Mr. Collins' proposal despite her discomfort.
Encourages Elizabeth to accept Mr. Collins' proposal based on social advancement.
Insists that Elizabeth marry Mr. Collins despite her refusal.
Insists on Elizabeth marrying Mr. Collins despite her refusal.
Laments the departure of the Netherfield family and feels concerned about the intimacy they had developed.
Persistently tries to push Elizabeth into accepting Mr. Collins's proposal for the sake of social advancement.
Expressed happiness and politeness in inviting Mr. Collins back to Longbourn.
Protests with perseverance and rudeness against Sir William's announcement.
Persists in disbelieving the engagement and expresses rude comments about the match.
Repeatedly expresses her impatience for Mr. Bingley's arrival and implies Jane would feel ill-used if he doesn't return.
Complains bitterly and expresses her jealousy and abhorrence towards Charlotte Lucas.
Expresses resentment about the entailment of the estate away from her daughters
Complains about her daughters' failed engagements and accuses neighbors of acting selfishly.
Expresses disappointment that her daughter Jane did not marry Mr. Bingley due to perceived social superior interventions.
Complains that Elizabeth refused Mr. Collins, causing another family to marry before hers.
Expresses ill-natured wishes for the happiness of Mr. Collins and Miss Lucas.
Expresses resigned approval of Mr. Collins' marriage in an ill-natured tone.
Engages fully in both listening to Jane's account of current fashions and relaying this info.
Expresses determination never to speak of Jane's heartbreak again.
Displays disdain for Mr. Bingley and hopes he will regret his actions.
Reproaches her elder daughters for their insensibility amidst Kitty and Lydia's misery.
Expresses happiness about Lydia's trip to Brighton and encourages her to enjoy herself
Remains ill and does not exert herself despite the family crisis.
Blames others and laments her own sufferings without taking responsibility.
Complains about her husband returning without their daughter and questions who will make Wickham marry her.
Expresses disappointment that Mr. Bennet did not force Wickham to marry Lydia.
Expresses boundless joy at Lydia’s impending marriage despite her prior misconduct.
Offers generous congratulations to everyone regarding Lydia’s marriage.
Expresses exuberant joy at Lydia's impending marriage, disregarding Lydia's past misconduct.
Is more concerned about her daughter's clothes than the shame of her eloping.
Shows no sentiment of shame and focuses on status symbols for her daughter's marriage
Welcomes Lydia and Wickham with rapture and wishes them happiness despite the circumstances.
Seeks maximum social visitation for Lydia despite the family's discomfort.
Welcomes Lydia and Wickham with rapture and shows no doubt of their happiness despite their elopement.
Welcomes Mr. Darcy politely for Mr. Bingley's sake despite her personal dislike.
Forcefully advocates social etiquette and early invitations to assert her family's position.
Occupied with happy schemes due to Bingley's politeness and hopes for Jane's marriage.
Forbore to invite Bingley to sit by her to allow Jane to interact with him.
Expresses great spirits and expectations after observing Bingley's behavior towards Jane.
Schemes for advantageous marriage of daughters.
Attempts to orchestrate social interactions to ensure advantageous marriage for her daughter.
Received Lady Catherine with utmost politeness despite the latter's rudeness.
Shows deference and politeness to Lady Catherine because of her higher social standing.
Criticizes Mr. Darcy as disagreeable and tiresome, showing initial reluctance and negativity towards him.
Changes opinion of Mr. Darcy after learning about his wealth.
Delighted at the marriage of her daughters to men of higher status.

Mr. Bennet.Action: Refuses to visit Mr. Bingley despite his wife's insistence and the potential benefit for their daughters.
Mocks his wife about her nerves and her insistence on visiting Mr. Bingley.
Suggests Mrs. Bennet and the girls visit Mr. Bingley instead, considering potential favorable attention toward his wife.
Suggests he has no particular plan to visit Mr. Bingley, despite societal expectations.
Visits Mr. Bingley despite claiming he would not.
Suggests Mrs. Bennet introduce Mr. Bingley to Mrs. Long.
Offers to take on the responsibility of introducing Mr. Bingley himself.
Protests against the description of Mr. Bingley's partners and wishes Mr. Bingley had sprained his ankle.
Calls his daughters 'uncommonly foolish'
Comments negatively about his daughters' interests and behavior.
Expressed real pleasure at their return though laconic.
Glad to see his daughters return but expresses it laconically, showing a lack of hierarchical concerns.
Expresses eagerness to meet Mr. Collins despite his pompous letter.
Acknowledges the hierarchical nature of the entail.
Chooses a subject for conversation which makes his guest, Mr. Collins, shine.
Remarks on Mr. Collins' flattery toward Lady Catherine.
Accepts Mr. Collins' request to play backgammon and calls the girls' interests trifling.
Instigates Mr. Collins to join daughters for walk to maintain personal tranquility
Stops Mary from singing again to let other young ladies exhibit.
Refuses to force Elizabeth into marriage, respecting her decision.
Refuses to insist that Elizabeth marry Mr. Collins and jokes that she must choose between her parents.
Expresses emotions of a most agreeable sort and makes light-hearted remarks about Charlotte and his wife.
Attempts to console Mrs. Bennet and encourages her to hope for better things.
Makes light of Jane's disappointment in love.
Jokes about romantic disappointments giving a sort of distinction.
Exclaims his gladness upon Elizabeth’s return voluntarily and repeatedly.
Gives vague and equivocal answers to his wife's discussion about going to Brighton.
Listens attentively to Elizabeth's concerns about Lydia.
Allows Lydia to go to Brighton despite Elizabeth's plea, aiming to keep domestic peace.
Allows Lydia to go to Brighton despite acknowledging her foolishness
Finds amusement in his wife's ignorance and folly instead of seeking pleasures that often console the unfortunate.
Shows philosophical composure and takes responsibility for the consequences of his own actions.
Intent on controlling the behavior of his children through strict measures.
Dislikes writing the letter himself but agrees to do it.
Coolly replies 'Just as you please' when asked if the girls should inform their mother of the news.
Feels ashamed that Wickham asked for so little money, indicating his belief in higher societal expectations.
Expresses gratitude to his brother-in-law and agrees to fulfill engagements made for him.
Refuses to buy clothes for his daughter Lydia for her marriage.
Expresses concern about social obligations and the economic provision for his family
Refuses to visit Mr. Bingley despite his wife's urging.
Resists social interaction etiquette, refusing to seek Mr. Bingley's society.
Congratulates Jane on her happiness and expresses pleasure for her future.
Shows general contentment with Bingley, acknowledging his daughter's happy relationship without any hierarchical consideration.
Shares Mr. Collins' concerns for the family in a teasing manner.
Treats Mr. Collins' letter and warnings lightly, dismissing the idea of social hierarchy.
After initial disbelief, he takes the time to get acquainted and grows to appreciate Mr. Darcy.
Expresses skepticism but ultimately respects Elizabeth's choice.
Mr. Bennet refused to let Kitty visit Lydia due to Lydia's poor influence.
Refused to let Kitty spend time with Lydia.

Elizabeth Bennet.Action: Reminds her mother that they will meet Mr. Bingley at assemblies.
Overhears Mr. Darcy's negative comments but tells the story with great spirit among her friends.
Allows Jane to like Mr. Bingley despite her reservations.
Comments on Jane's tendency to like people in general and not see faults in others.
Remains silent and unconvinced about Mr. Bingley's sisters' charm.
Promises her mother that she will never dance with Mr. Darcy.
Cannot like the kindness shown to Jane due to overall treatment of everyone.
States Jane's feelings cannot be hurried for the purpose of securing a marriage.
Mentions Mr. Darcy's behavior critically to Charlotte.
Resists playing music initially but agrees due to Miss Lucas's insistence.
Refuses to dance with Mr. Darcy despite Sir William Lucas's persuasion.
Disapproves of the superficial kindness from higher social classes.
Determines to visit her sick sister Jane despite adverse conditions
Chooses to walk through dirty weather to care for her sister, disregarding societal expectations.
Dedicates herself to nursing her sick sister Jane, refusing to leave her side until she is asleep.
Defends her own preference for reading and expresses opinions counter to social norms regarding female accomplishments.
Passed the chief of the night in her sister’s room.
Requested to have a note sent to Longbourn, desiring her mother to visit Jane.
Tried to steer the conversation to prevent her mother's embarrassment.
Defends Mr. Darcy's opinion about local society.
Attempts to engage with Mr. Darcy's questioning despite her reluctance.
Refuses to dance a reel with Mr. Darcy, aiming to subvert his expectation of contempt.
Observes Mr. Darcy's interest in her without feeling any inclination towards social approval.
Runs off from the walk, choosing independence over fitting into the group.
Agrees to walk around the room with Miss Bingley despite being surprised by the suggestion.
Expresses enjoyment at watching Mr. Bingley’s attentiveness to her sister Jane.
Refrains from ridiculing Mr. Darcy when he speaks about serious subjects.
Laughs at follies and nonsense, indicating a lack of concern for hierarchy.
Wrote to her mother requesting the carriage.
Urged Jane to borrow Mr. Bingley's carriage to leave sooner.
Positively resolved against staying longer at Netherfield despite pressures.
Finds interest in Mr. Collins' letter but sees his deference for Lady Catherine as extraordinary.
Questions Mr. Collins’ servility and self-importance.
Engaging in conversation and socializing with Mr. Wickham.
Responding sympathetically to Mr. Wickham's grievances against Mr. Darcy.
Criticizing Mr. Darcy's pride openly.
Expresses skepticism and does not laugh Jane out of her opinion.
Feels delighted at the prospect of dancing with Mr. Wickham and anticipates a pleasant confirmation of Mr. Darcy's behavior.
Accepts Mr. Collins' proposal to dance with as good a grace as she could, despite her own preferences.
Chooses not to quarrel about Mr. Collins and dismisses the hint about marriage, avoiding a serious dispute.
Accepts Mr. Collins' proposal to dance despite preferring Mr. Wickham.
Hardly reply with tolerable civility to Darcy's polite inquiries.
Tells her griefs to Charlotte Lucas.
Changes the discourse to one more gratifying to Jane.
Endeavours to prevent Mary from singing all night.
Expresses happiness about being able to dance opposite to Mr. Darcy due to his social standing.
Treats Mr. Darcy with contempt after perceiving his treatment of Wickham.
Feels capable of liking Bingley’s two sisters due to Jane’s potential marriage despite recognizing their contempt for her family.
Shows concern for Jane’s happiness over social considerations.
Attempts to communicate her refusal sincerely and rationally.
Refuses Mr. Collins' marriage proposal despite social expectations.
Expresses the importance of her personal happiness over social expectations.
Refuses Mr. Collins' proposal.
Feels anxiety about Jane's distress and follows her upstairs to discuss the letter.
Comforts Jane and advises her to consider her feelings over the opinions of Bingley's sisters.
Supports Jane and suggests Miss Bingley is deceiving herself to keep her brother away for social reasons.
Thanks Charlotte for her kindness.
Exprssed astonishment on Charlotte's engagement and wished her imaginable happiness.
Quietly answers Charlotte's statement and returns to the family.
Attempts to reconcile with Charlotte's decision for marriage to Mr. Collins.
Endeavours to put a stop to the exclamations of her mother and sisters by congratulating Sir William.
Promotes the happiness of others and does not focus on hierarchical status
Expresses silent indignation regarding Caroline and her brother.
Speaks critically of Mr. Collins's character and Charlotte's marriage.
Speaks harshly about Mr. Bingley's sisters and their intentions.
Speaks negatively about Mr. Darcy.
Dismisses Caroline's assertion that her brother is partial to Miss Darcy and criticizes his lack of resolution influenced by his friends.
Consoles her aunt and engages in a reasoned conversation about Jane's failed romance.
Expresses solicitude over Jane's situation, reflecting genuine concern.
Cynically remarks that general incivility is the essence of love.
Mocks Mr. Darcy's disdain for socially inferior places.
Believes Mr. Bingley could rekindle his affection for Jane despite his friend's higher social influence.
Thanks her aunt for her advice.
Promises her aunt to refrain from encouraging Mr. Wickham's visit frequently.
Expresses regret for her mother's ungracious wishes and sincerely accompanies Miss Lucas out of the room.
Agrees to visit Charlotte despite foreseeing little pleasure in the visit.
Acknowledges societal expectations but questions her ability to resist the same behaviors seen in others.
Feels discomfort at Charlotte's choice but resolves to maintain correspondence and visit.
Expresses neutral feelings towards Miss King and acceptance of realistic social outcomes.
Accepts an invitation from her uncle and aunt for a tour of pleasure and expresses disdain for men with neither manners nor sense, showing openness to experiences beyond hierarchical dominance.
Rejects Mr. Collins’ attempts to impress her with his social standing.
Answers Lady Catherine's impertinent questions composedly.
Answers Lady Catherine's questions composedly and refuses to provide a direct answer about her age, challenging Lady Catherine's authority.
Questions Mr. Darcy about her sister without fear of social reproach.
Laughing heartily and engaging in playful conversation.
Receiving Lady Catherine's criticisms with civil forbearance.
Playing at the request of the gentlemen until Lady Catherine's carriage was ready.
Dismisses the intimidation attempt by Mr. Darcy.
Mocks Darcy for not seeking introductions at a ball.
Engaged in conversation to avoid total silence.
Decided to leave Mr. Darcy to find a subject when conversation faltered.
Critiqued Mr. Collins' choice of wife.
Upon seeing Colonel Fitzwilliam approaching, she puts away Jane’s letter and forces a smile to greet him.
Expresses her thoughts frankly about Mr. Darcy’s interference in his friend's romantic inclinations rather than blindly condemning him.
Questions Mr. Darcy's right to interfere in Mr. Bingley's romantic life based on his own judgment.
Intended to exasperate herself by examining Jane's letters.
Resolving to console Jane and help her recover her spirits.
Responding to Mr. Darcy with cold civility.
Trying to compose herself to answer Mr. Darcy with patience.
Rejecting Mr. Darcy's proposal and expressing her resentment.
Accusing Mr. Darcy of ruining her sister's happiness.
Defending Mr. Wickham against Mr. Darcy.
Speaking with composure despite growing anger.
Expressing her strong dislike for Mr. Darcy.
Decides to continue walking despite her reluctance to encounter Mr. Darcy.
Chooses to read Mr. Darcy’s letter despite initial disgust and shock, showing openness and critical engagement with hierarchical assertions.
Chooses to reconsider Mr. Darcy’s letter and weighs the evidence impartially, despite her previous prejudices.
Takes the initiative to appear cheerful and repress negative reflections upon returning home.
Expresses regret and shame upon realizing her blind prejudice and the harm it has caused.
Refuses to open and consider Mr. Darcy’s letter again after first reading it.
Feels satisfaction in missing Colonel Fitzwilliam.
Critically evaluates Darcy's objections and Wickham's claims, indicating her struggle with hierarchical views.
Refused Lady Catherine's invitation to stay longer.
Attempted to restrain the imprudence of her younger sisters.
Expresses thanks and assurances of happiness for the hospitality received.
Adds her respects and grateful thanks to the ladies of Rosings upon Mr. Collins's reminder.
Privately decides to conceal certain details from Maria.
Refrains from discussing Mr. Darcy's proposals and Mr. Bingley to avoid further upsetting Jane.
Does not express objection when reminded to leave respects for the ladies of Rosings.
Opposes Lydia's scheme to walk to Meryton and see the officers, prioritizing social propriety.
Opposes Lydia's proposal to walk to Meryton to see the officers.
Feels great satisfaction at the regiment's departure.
Decides to suppress details to protect her sister's feelings.
Expresses regret and compassion for Mr. Darcy.
Decides not to expose Wickham's character to protect his reputation.
Decides not to publicly reveal Wickham's true character.
Attempts to make Kitty reasonable about her situation.
Attempts to persuade her father not to let Lydia go to Brighton by representing the improprieties of Lydia’s behavior.
Represses Mr. Wickham's frivolous gallantry towards her and is indifferent about it.
Disapproves of Lydia's trip to Brighton and advises her father against it
Endeavours to forget her father's impropriety and strives to banish the thoughts of his continual breach of conjugal obligation.
Tries to console herself for present disappointment by looking forward to a tour to the Lakes.
Feels it is her business to be satisfied and soon finds herself happy with a more contracted tour when the original plan is delayed.
Feels gratitude and admiration for Mr. Darcy due to his positive characteristics as a brother, landlord, and master.
Expresses astonishment and embarrassment at Mr. Darcy's civility and contrasting manner.
Confirms Mr. Darcy's good character and refutes Wickham's claims.
Talking amiably with Darcy who she previously had disliked and misunderstood.
Respecting and esteeming Mr. Darcy despite previously rejecting him.
Feels gratitude and respect for Mr. Darcy despite his previous social intimidations.
Engages in conversation despite being closely watched by Miss Bingley.
Engages in conversation despite being closely watched, responds calmly to Miss Bingley's ill-natured comment.
Experiences distress and immediately seeks help from her uncle to address her sister's predicament.
Feels regret for not having shared information that could have prevented her sister's elopement.
Expresses regret and self-reproach for not warning others about Wickham.
Expresses sorrow for what her father must have endured and cautions him against being too severe on himself.
Critically assesses the deference given to her by Mr. Gardiner.
Encourages her father to answer the letter immediately, emphasizing the importance of each moment.
Takes her father's letter to read to her mother.
Reflects on the sacrifice and kindness of her uncle and aunt and acknowledges their actions.
Voices regret that Wickham and Lydia must marry despite their poor prospects for happiness.
Regrets confiding in Mr. Darcy about her sister Lydia's situation.
Urges Mr. Bennet to receive Lydia and her husband at Longbourn for the sake of Lydia's feelings.
Regrets informing Mr. Darcy about her sister’s elopement, fearing it reflects poorly on her family
Feels disgusted and shocked by Lydia and Wickham but avoids conflict by staying silent.
Runs out of the room because she cannot bear Lydia's behavior.
Gratefully declines Lydia’s offer to find husbands for her sisters.
Writes to her aunt to inquire about Mr. Darcy’s presence at Lydia’s wedding.
Expresses disdain for Lydia's way of getting husbands.
Decided to engage civilly with Wickham despite knowing his faults.
Offered her hand to Wickham and expressed hopes for future harmony.
Attempts to comfort her sister Jane and shorten her discomfort.
Experiences discomfort and avoids conversation due to the shame induced by her mother's social maneuvering.
Feels that Mr. Darcy's kindness is neither unknown nor unfelt despite her mother's ungraciousness.
Follows Mr. Darcy with her eyes, envying others whom he speaks to despite her anger with herself.
Desires to converse with Mr. Darcy despite social discomfort.
Congratulates Jane with sincerity, warmth, and delight, which Jane finds immensely pleasing.
Minimizes her reaction to her mother's machinations and shows no interest in separating herself from family or social hierarchy.
Refused to promise Lady Catherine that she would never enter into an engagement with Mr. Darcy.
Told Lady Catherine firmly that her arguments and interference were frivolous and ill-judged.
Displayed courtesy by attending Lady Catherine despite her rude behavior.
Refused to be intimidated by Lady Catherine's demands and stood her ground regarding her relationship with Mr. Darcy.
Refuses to bow to Lady Catherine's demands and supports the right for personal choice in marriage regardless of social class.
Feels unease reflecting on Lady Catherine's interference and possible consequences.
Accepts her family's teasing quietly despite feeling mortified.
Laughs at her father's question about Lady Catherine without revealing distress.
Expresses distaste for Lady Catherine's interference and Mr. Collins' warnings.
Thanks Mr. Darcy for his kindness towards her sister.
Admits to having long been ashamed of her past harsh words to Mr. Darcy.
Expresses gratitude towards Mr. Darcy for his efforts and compassion for her family.
Expresses gratitude and admiration for Darcy's unexampled kindness towards her sister despite class differences.
Boldly walks alone with Darcy to speak her mind and resolve misunderstandings.
Ensures the application for her mother's consent is handled carefully and avoids any inconvenience for Mr. Darcy.
Speaks positively of Darcy despite family disapproval.
Wanted Mr. Darcy to account for his feelings.
Acknowledged her past behavior and teasing towards Mr. Darcy.
Wrote to her aunt Mrs. Gardiner with joyful news to share happiness.
Protected Mr. Darcy from uncomfortable interactions with her relatives.
Elizabeth persuaded Darcy to seek a reconciliation with Lady Catherine.
Elizabeth frequently sent relief to Wickham and Lydia despite their extravagance.
Refused to ask Mr. Darcy for financial help for Lydia and Wickham.

Kitty Bennet.Action: Responds fretfully when her coughing is criticized.
Reproaches her elder sisters for their insensibility amidst her own extreme misery.
Complains about not receiving an invitation to Brighton despite not being Mrs. Forster's friend
Cries seriously after her father prohibits her from social activities due to her sister's misconduct.
Expresses her hope to follow her sister's socially advantageous path.

Lydia Bennet.Action: Confidently mentions that Mr. Bingley will dance with her despite being the youngest.
Offers to accompany Elizabeth part of the way on her walk
Shows open admiration for officers based on their status.
Demanded Mr. Bingley keep his promise to give a ball at Netherfield.
Shows no interest in Mr. Collins because he didn't come in a scarlet coat.
Shows disinterest in Mr. Collins due to his lack of social appeal.
Expresses disinterest in 'Fordyce's Sermons' and discusses other trivial matters.
Determined to find out who the stranger was
Stays to eavesdrop on the conversation despite others leaving.
Stays to hear Mrs. Bennet's conversation with Mr. Collins despite being told to hold her tongue.
Boisterously exclaims in an uncivil manner that Mr. Collins wants to marry her sister Elizabeth.
Triumphantly welcomes her sisters and offers them lunch at the inn.
Ignores Mary's reply during conversation.
Expresses a desire for her father to take them to Brighton to be near the soldiers.
Proclaims that she would be ashamed of not being married before twenty-three.
Insists she should chaperon her sisters to balls once married.
Calls her father 'disagreeable' for not allowing a trip to Brighton.
Is wholly inattentive to her sister's feelings while celebrating her invitation to Brighton.
Celebrates her invitation to Brighton and flaunts it in front of her sister
Promises to write very often to her mother and Kitty but sends short letters instead.
Insensitively demands congratulations and boasts about her marriage.
Demands congratulations from her sisters and boasts about being married.
Takes Jane's place at the mother's right hand because she is a married woman.
Longs to see neighbors and hear herself called 'Mrs. Wickham'.
Shows off her ring and marriage to the housemaids.
Expresses envy if her sisters don't have her 'good luck' and plans to secure husbands for them as well.
Ignored advice and assistance offered by Mr. Darcy.
Lydia and Wickham frequently overstayed their welcome, prompting even Bingley to talk about giving them a hint to leave.

Mr. Bingley.Action: Makes himself acquainted with all the principal people in the room and plans to give a ball himself.
Encourages Mr. Darcy to dance and engage with the people at the assembly.
Advocates for dancing with all the ladies at the assembly regardless of their social standing and appearance.
Feels acquainted with everyone at the Meryton assembly and finds them pleasant and attentive.
Shows good-humour and kindness towards Elizabeth
Expresses evident anxiety for Jane's well-being and offers to fetch books for Elizabeth.
Recommends sending for Mr. Jones and ensuring Jane receives every possible attention.
Expresses genuine care and solicitude for Jane Bennet's health, regardless of her lower social connections.
Welcomed and offered to host Jane at Netherfield.
Assured Lydia of a ball at Netherfield when Jane was recovered.
Critiques his own writing style, showing humility and openness to self-reflection.
Shows concern for Jane Bennet's comfort by piling up the fire and suggesting she move to another side of the fireplace.
Shows diffused warmth and joy in his interaction with Jane Bennet and talks scarcely to anyone else.
Expressed real sorrow and tried to persuade Jane to stay longer for her health.
Expressing unaffected cordiality and friendliness towards Elizabeth and her family.
Shows admiration for Jane Bennet in a guarded manner.
Bores with the ill-judged officiousness of Mrs. Bennet and listens to her silly remarks with forbearance.
Proposes a group walk to be alone with Jane.
Forgives Mr. Darcy for hiding Jane's presence in town.

Mr. Darcy.Action: Refuses to dance and dismisses the women at the assembly as not worth his time.
Refuses to dance with ladies he is not acquainted with, claiming it would be insupportable.
Comments that Elizabeth Bennet is 'tolerable, but not handsome enough' to tempt him.
Expresses a critical view of the people at the Meryton assembly.
Sits close to Mrs. Long for half an hour without speaking to her.
Requests to be allowed the honor of Elizabeth's hand in dance after being prompted by Sir William Lucas.
Criticizes the lower social circles and expresses disdain for them.
Expresses doubt about Elizabeth walking so far alone, reflecting societal norms.
Agrees that Miss Elizabeth Bennet should not have walked alone through the mud, indicating a lack of understanding of her motivations.
Critiques the arts women employ for captivation, calling them despicable.
Believes marrying a person with lower social connections materially lessens one's chance of marrying men of consideration.
Writes a letter despite interruptions from Miss Bingley.
Requests music and interacts politely with Elizabeth and Miss Bingley.
Suggests moving to a wider path to avoid leaving Elizabeth alone.
Refuses Miss Bingley's offer to mend his pen, indicating his self-sufficiency.
Writes a detailed letter to his sister, demonstrating a sense of duty and control.
Declines to join Elizabeth and Miss Bingley walking around the room, implying he would be interfering with their motives.
States that his good opinion, once lost, is lost forever and admits to a resentful temper.
Chose to avoid Elizabeth and barely spoke to her.
Resolved to be careful that no sign of admiration for Elizabeth should escape him to avoid influencing his felicity.
Barely acknowledges Mr. Wickham with a slight return of his salutation.
Unstated but implied treatment of Mr. Wickham and distancing from lower-class interactions.
Responds to Mr. Collins with distant civility.
Displays hauteur and a deeper shade of superiority upon hearing about Elizabeth's new acquaintance with Mr. Wickham.
Pays reserved compliments to Mrs. Collins but engages minimally.
Expressing affectionate praise of his sister’s proficiency in music.
Smiling while mentioning weaknesses in his own social skills.
Moving towards the piano to command a full view of Elizabeth's performance.
Expressing his difficulty in conversing easily with strangers.
Speaks with affectionate praise of his sister's proficiency.
Feels ashamed of Lady Catherine's ill-breeding and makes no answer.
Apologized for his intrusion.
Attempted to initiate conversation about the comfort of the house.
Suggested that distance to family is manageable.
Experienced a change of feeling and drew back his chair.
Engaged in a short dialogue about Kent in a calm and concise manner.
Taken measures to separate Mr. Bingley and Jane due to perceived strong objections against Jane.
Interferes to prevent an imprudent marriage between Mr. Bingley and Jane.
Boasting about the misery he inflicted on others.
Inquiring after Elizabeth's health in a hurried manner.
Expressing his feelings for Elizabeth ardently and without regard for her feelings.
Expressing real security about his proposal despite Elizabeth's visible astonishment.
Responding to Elizabeth with forced calmness and resentment.
Rejoicing in his success in separating his friend from Elizabeth's sister.
Expressing contempt for Mr. Wickham's misfortunes.
Acknowledging his actions against Mr. Wickham and showing no remorse.
Expressing his opinion that Elizabeth's pride was hurt by his honest confession.
Leaving the room hastily and expressing shame for his feelings.
Admits to adopting measures of concealment to protect his friend from an unhappy marriage.
Writes a detailed explanatory letter to Elizabeth to clarify his actions and motives.
Expresses regret for paining Elizabeth but proceeds with explaining his actions.
Attempts to prevent Mr. Bingley from marrying Elizabeth's sister due to social class concerns.
Describes objections to a match based on social status and family connections.
Disappointed by Elizabeth's refusal and the belief that he would succeed in his proposal.
Shows civility and attentiveness to Mr. Gardiner, invites him to fish and offers to provide tackle.
Shows unassuming politeness to Elizabeth's relatives and offers fishing tackle and permission to fish on his grounds to Mr. Gardiner.
Courting the good opinion of people with whom any intercourse a few months ago would have been a disgrace.
Calling on his sister to join him in expressing their wish to see Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner, and Miss Bennet to dinner at Pemberley.
Polite and seeking the good opinion of people he previously disdained.
Expresses admiration for Elizabeth despite Miss Bingley's criticism.
Defends Elizabeth against Miss Bingley's criticisms.
Shows concern for Elizabeth's distress and offers assistance.
Respects Elizabeth’s need for privacy and promptly leaves the room.
Shrinks from the idea of familial alliance with Wickham due to his social standing
Went to great lengths to assist in resolving Lydia's situation, taking on the trouble and mortification of dealing with Wickham.
Paid off Wickham's debts and ensured a marriage between Lydia and Wickham.
Did not seek acknowledgment or gratitude for his actions.
Attends the visit at the Bennet household, likely out of consideration for Bingley and Elizabeth.
Silent, grave, and indifferent behavior around Elizabeth.
Expresses regret and acknowledges the justice of Elizabeth's past reproofs.
Shares his personal growth and thanks Elizabeth for teaching him a valuable lesson.
Acknowledges his past wrong actions and shows willingness to improve relationships.
Confesses to Mr. Bingley about his previous wrongdoings and seeks to rectify the situation.
Confesses past behavior influenced by pride and conceit due to his upbringing, but acknowledges improving due to Elizabeth's influence.
Interferes in Bingley and Jane's relationship initially based on social prejudices but later rectifies his action by supporting their engagement.
Acknowledges his mistaken interference and respects Elizabeth's family despite initial prejudices.
Voluntarily helped Lydia by making up the match, giving money, paying debts, and securing a commission for Wickham.
Listened to Elizabeth and responded sincerely about his feelings.
Praised Elizabeth for her lively mind rather than her impertinence.
Bore the obsequious civility of Mr. Collins calmly.
Reconciled with Lady Catherine due to familial ties.

Jane Bennet.Action: Expresses admiration for Mr. Bingley and his agreeable manners.
Speaks positively about Mr. Bingley's sisters despite their behavior.
Defends Mr. Darcy's behavior to Mrs. Bennet.
Receives attention with great pleasure.
Firm in her decision to leave Netherfield where she felt herself to be right.
Acknowledges Mr. Collins' intention to make amends as a creditable wish.
Thought well of both Mr. Darcy and Mr. Wickham, defending their conduct and attributing misunderstandings to accidents or mistakes.
Acknowledges Mr. Darcy's potential unkindness but defends the conduct of both Darcy and Wickham.
Defends both Mr. Darcy and Mr. Wickham, rationalizing the conflict without blaming either party.
Declines to interfere with Elizabeth’s decision but does so mildly.
Refuses to interfere in Elizabeth's decision.
Tries to join general conversation despite feeling upset.
Believes Caroline Bingley is incapable of wilfully deceiving anyone.
Still hopes for Mr. Bingley’s return despite his sister's interference.
Readily joins Elizabeth in congratulating Sir William and makes remarks on the happiness of the match.
Expresses earnest desire for Charlotte and Mr. Collins's happiness despite her astonishment.
Steadily maintains mildness in response to her mother's attacks.
Expresses earnest desire for Charlotte Lucas and Mr. Collins' happiness without considering their social status
Expresses that she will not repine despite her mother's pain-inducing remarks.
Speaks optimistically about Mr. Bingley despite her disappointment.
Defends Charlotte's character and expresses hope for her happiness with Mr. Collins.
Urges Elizabeth to take Mr. Bingley's actions in the best light.
Pleads for allowances and urged the possibility of mistakes regarding Mr. Darcy.
Suggests making allowances for differences of situation and temper.
Mild and steady candour pleads for allowances and the possibility of mistakes regarding Mr. Darcy.
Pities Caroline for her behavior despite feeling wronged by her actions.
Shows concern about maintaining social connections despite Caroline Bingley's apparent lack of regard.
Displays complacency in her air and manner despite fervent feelings, suggesting lack of struggle with social hierarchy.
Expresses sorrow for Mr. Darcy's disappointment despite his flaws.
Expresses shock and sympathy for Mr. Darcy.
Expresses sorrow for Mr. Darcy's disappointment and unhappiness.
Agrees to take care of her cousins with affection and intelligence.
Expresses hope and requests immediate assistance despite distressing news.
Welcomes her uncle and aunt with alternate smiles and tears, remains hopeful.
Offers to write the letter for Mr. Bennet to save him the trouble.
Hopes for Lydia and Wickham's happiness despite their imprudent behavior.
Urges Mr. Bennet to receive Lydia and her husband at Longbourn for the sake of Lydia's feelings.
Persuades her father to receive Lydia and her husband despite the disgrace
Feels distressed and sympathetic for Lydia’s situation.
Stops Lydia from revealing more secrets.
Maintains propriety and avoids unnecessary complaisance in her interaction with Mr. Bingley.
Satisfied with non-romantic interaction with Mr. Bingley.
Acknowledges her happiness with liveliness and wishes everyone could be as happy.
Hurries to inform her mother of her happiness to personally share the good news.
Shows distress at her mother's premeditated schemes and values equal happiness for everyone.
Congratulates Elizabeth and expresses happiness for her sister's engagement despite initial disbelief.
Shows acceptance of Elizabeth's marriage to Darcy despite initial disbelief.
Responded kindly to Miss Bingley's insincere congratulations.

Sir William Lucas.Action: Occupying himself solely in being civil to all the world despite being elated by his rank.
Attempts to socialize with Mr. Darcy and talks about superior society.
Gives consent for Charlotte and Mr. Collins's marriage.
Believes it would be expedient for Mr. Collins and his wife to make their appearance at St. James’s when in possession of the Longbourn estate.
He unfolds the matter of his daughter's engagement with compliments and self-gratulation.
Listens to all their impertinence with the most forbearing courtesy.
Sir William's civilities are described as worn out, indicating that his social dominance and hierarchical views are well-known and tiresome.
Constantly bows in earnest contemplation of Miss De Bourgh’s greatness.

Mary Bennet.Action: Reflects on pride and vanity as common failings in human nature.
Critiques the composition of Mr. Collins' letter.
Attempts to find merit in Mr. Collins’ formal letter.
Has no disinclination for the ball and believes in society's claims on everyone, considering recreation and amusement desirable for everybody.
Expresses willingness to join evening engagements for social obligations.
Prefers reading a book over engaging in social activities.
Delivers moralistic speeches that do not directly address immediate concerns.

Charlotte Lucas.Action: Discusses strategies for securing a marriage that differ from Jane's spontaneous feelings.
Did not actively support Mrs. Bennet in urging Elizabeth to marry Mr. Collins.
Listens to Mr. Collins to keep him in good humor and prevent him from returning his addresses to Elizabeth.
Assured Elizabeth she was satisfied in being useful and that it repaid her for the little sacrifice of her time.
Expresses hope that Elizabeth will be satisfied with her actions after thinking it over.
Engages Mr. Collins to secure herself from return of his addresses towards Elizabeth.
Accepts Mr. Collins solely for the desire of an establishment despite his lack of amiable qualities.
Submits to Elizabeth her non-romantic, pragmatic view on marriage.
Accepts her new social position and associated comforts and expresses cheerfulness about it.
Encourages Mr. Collins to work in the garden to maintain peace and comfort in the house.
Organizes the household to avoid Mr. Collins' dominance yet complies with social expectations.
Chooses marriage to Mr. Collins with her eyes open, despite his social aspirations.

Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley.Action: Express superciliousness towards those of lower social standing.

Miss Bingley.Action: Mocks the lower social circles and criticizes their insipidity.
Offers Elizabeth the carriage and invites her to stay
Shows politeness and offers Elizabeth the carriage to help her.
Abuses Elizabeth once she leaves the room and criticizes her harshly.
Concurs with Darcy's high standards for accomplished women and criticizes Elizabeth for undervaluing other women.
Recommends an express to town for a physician but offers little practical help.
Mocks Elizabeth Bennet's appearance and independence while emphasizing her attention to social decorum.
Assured that Jane would receive every possible attention while she remains at Netherfield, albeit with cold civility.
Performed her part without much graciousness.
Attempts to provoke Darcy against Elizabeth Bennet.
Observes Mr. Darcy while he writes and repeatedly interrupts him.
Compliments Mr. Darcy excessively to gain his favor.
Attempts to provoke Darcy into disliking Elizabeth by talking about their supposed marriage and her family's social status.
Makes continuous attempts to engage Mr. Darcy in conversation despite his lack of interest.
Suggests waking Mr. Hurst to play music.
Suggests consulting the wishes of the party about holding a ball to accommodate Mr. Darcy's preferences.
Increased civility to Elizabeth and affection for Jane.
Shows jealousy and dislike of Elizabeth, while being more affectionate towards Jane.
Speaks to Elizabeth with expression of civil disdain.
Says that Wickham's guilt and descent are the same and expresses disdain against Wickham due to his lower social standing.
Boasts of increasing intimacy with Miss Darcy and predicts the accomplishment of class-based wishes.
Watch Elizabeth closely out of jealousy and makes a sneering remark to discompose her.
Criticizes Elizabeth's appearance to Darcy.
Expresses jealousy and criticizes Elizabeth's appearance and character.
Miss Bingley paid off every arrear of civility to Elizabeth after Darcy's marriage.
Dropped resentment to retain the right to visit Pemberley.

Catherine Bennet.Action: Offers to accompany Elizabeth part of the way on her walk
Shows no interest in Mr. Collins because he didn't come in a scarlet coat.
Shows disinterest in Mr. Collins due to his lack of social appeal.

Mr. Hurst.Action: Shows indifference towards Elizabeth and prefers to focus on eating, drinking, and playing cards.
Shows disinterest in Elizabeth's preference for reading over playing cards, expressing astonishment.
Falls asleep on the sofa instead of engaging with the group or playing cards.

Mrs. Hurst.Action: Echoes Miss Bingley's negative comments about Elizabeth.
Agrees with Miss Bingley's mockery of Elizabeth Bennet and expresses disdain for her family's lower social connections.
Shows indifference to Elizabeth and Mrs. Gardiner.

Darcy.Action: Criticizes the variety of people in the country.
Displays cold salutation towards Mr. Wickham
Darcy assisted Wickham further in his profession despite never receiving him at Pemberley.
Refused to receive Wickham at Pemberley.

Mr. Collins.Action: Writes a letter seeking to heal the breach between families and expresses readiness to make amends to Mr. Bennet's daughters.
Compliments Mrs. Bennet on her fine family of daughters and expresses intent to admire them.
Apologizes repeatedly for displeasing Mrs. Bennet.
Expresses deference to Lady Catherine de Bourgh and accepts the hierarchical structure of inheritance.
Offers flattering compliments to Lady Catherine, although they are somewhat insincere.
Expresses frustration at Lydia's interruption but does not bear ill-will towards her.
Stops reading and offers to play a game with Mr. Bennet.
Praises Lady Catherine's affability and rank.
Remarks on Miss de Bourgh's distinguished birth.
Expresses pleasure in offering compliments to Lady Catherine.
Refuses to read novels from a circulating library.
Accepts Mr. Bennet's invitation to join his daughters on their walk.
Apologizes for intruding on Mrs. Philips and shows gratitude for her politeness.
Veneration for Lady Catherine de Bourgh’s high rank
Self-importance as a clergyman
Chooses Elizabeth as potential wife after being cautioned against Jane
Resists scruples about leaving Mr. and Mrs. Bennet for an evening to join the engagement.
Compliments Mrs. Philips’s house by comparing it to Lady Catherine's mansion.
Sits down to play whist, obliging Mrs. Philips.
Assures Mrs. Philips not to worry about his money loss in the game.
Admiring the furniture of the drawing-room and comparing it to Lady Catherine's mansion.
Describing the grandeur of Lady Catherine and her mansion.
Acknowledging his thanks to Lady Catherine de Bourgh for removing him beyond regarding little matters.
Expressing gratitude towards Mr. and Mrs. Philips.
Solicits Elizabeth for the first two dances at the ball.
Enthusiastically approaches Mr. Darcy to pay respects due to Lady Catherine.
Remains close to Elizabeth the whole evening despite her wishes.
Expresses excitement about introducing himself to Mr. Darcy because of his connection to Lady Catherine de Bourgh.
Ignores Elizabeth's repeated and clear refusals.
Seeks approval from Lady Catherine de Bourgh for marriage decisions.
Proposes marriage to Elizabeth Bennet with the rationale of his social and familial position.
Speaks highly of Lady Catherine de Bourgh’s manners and rank as an advantage in his power to offer.
Believes Elizabeth's refusals are customary and expects her eventual acceptance due to social hierarchy.
Considers Elizabeth's refusal might be due to genuine character delicacy.
Expresses resignation and apologizes for any offense caused.
Suggested that Elizabeth might not be a desirable wife if she is headstrong and foolish.
Expresses feelings through stiffness of manner and resentful silence after rejection.
Displays stiffness of manner and resentful silence after Elizabeth rejects his marriage proposal.
Earnestly entreats Charlotte to name the day that would make him the happiest of men.
Thanks Mrs. Bennet for her invitation and promises to return as soon as possible.
Avoids notice by his cousins to keep his intentions secret until success.
Displays gratitude and duty by keeping Mr. Bennet’s caution about Lady Catherine’s disapproval.
Wishes his fair cousins health and happiness again and promises their father another letter of thanks.
Elizabeth's disgust towards Mr. Collins, despite absence weakening it, indicates that Mr. Collins exhibits behavior and attitudes that support hierarchical social structures.
Punctually repeated all his wife’s offers of refreshment.
Invited them to admire his garden and house, showcasing his hospitality.
Expressed high regard for Lady Catherine de Bourgh.
Welcomes guests with ostentatious formality and emphasizes his connections to higher social status individuals.
Instructs Elizabeth not to be uneasy about her apparel.
Recommends being quick as Lady Catherine objects to being kept waiting.
Commends and praises every dish at dinner.
Delights in displaying Lady Catherine's grandeur and is awed by her civility towards him.
Devotedly reports to Lady Catherine and shares information on local activities.
Despite Elizabeth's genuine illness, he reveals apprehension about Lady Catherine’s displeasure rather than concern for Elizabeth’s well-being.
Hastened to console Lady Catherine and her daughter after a melancholic scene.
Pays parting civilities and expresses gratitude for Elizabeth's company.
Expresses gratitude for condescension and connection with superior society at Rosings.
Condoles with Mr. Bennet and offers arguments to alleviate his misfortune.
Encourages Mr. Bennet to disown Lydia to protect the family's reputation.
Warns Elizabeth about possible evils of marrying Darcy due to family objections from Lady Catherine.

Lydia.Action: Interrupts Mr. Collins while he is reading.

Elizabeth.Action: Walks with her sisters including Mr. Collins as instructed by her father.
Listens with all her heart to Mr. Wickham's stories.
Converses with Mr. Wickham and agrees with his rational accounts.

Mr. Wickham.Action: Engages in polite and readiness of conversation with the ladies.
Joins regiment and engages in agreeable conversation
Engages Elizabeth in conversation and answers her questions.
Observes Mr. Collins and engages in conversation about his connections.
Receiving delight and attention between Elizabeth and Lydia and engaging in the conversation.
Criticizing Mr. Darcy for giving the living to another man.
Grateful towards Elizabeth's sympathy regarding his situation.
Discussing general topics such as Meryton, neighborhood, and society with Elizabeth Bennet.
Acknowledging Lady Catherine de Bourgh's reputation.
Avoids Mr. Darcy at the Netherfield ball, imposing his absence self-willingly.
Openly acknowledges his claims on Mr. Darcy, contributing to Darcy's condemnation by society.
Mr. Wickham's friendly farewell and solicitude show that he considers Elizabeth’s opinions of social hierarchy, such as that of Lady Catherine de Bourgh, important.
Pursues Georgiana Darcy for financial gain, highlighting opportunistic behavior rather than adherence to social hierarchy.
Engages with militia and attempts to advance his status through mercenary motives.
Expresses disdain for Mr. Darcy and implies he behaves due to fear of his aunt

Mr. Denny.Action: Pleasantly introduces Mr. Wickham to the ladies.
Introduces Mr. Wickham to the group

Mrs. Philips.Action: Politely receives Mr. Collins despite their lack of previous acquaintance.
Listens attentively to Mr. Collins’s descriptions of Lady Catherine's grandeur.
Provides Mr. Collins with coffee and muffins.
Spreads news of the upcoming advantageous marriage, reinforcing the family's heightened social status.

Kitty and Lydia.Action: Leads the way to find out about the stranger.

Mr. Bingley's sisters.Action: Paid little attention to the rest of the family and avoided Mrs. Bennet as much as possible.

Mr. Bingley and his sisters.Action: Avoid Mrs. Bennet and pay little attention to Elizabeth and other Bennet sisters.

Miss Lucas.Action: Displays civility in listening to Mr. Collins, providing relief to everyone.

Caroline Bingley.Action: Attempts to manipulate Jane Bennet's feelings by suggesting her brother Charles is interested in Miss Darcy.
Shows inattention towards Jane by not seeing or hearing from her for a week.
Makes a slight and formal apology for not calling on Jane sooner.

Lady Lucas.Action: Joyfully bestows consent for Charlotte's marriage.
Calculates Mr. Bennet's expected lifespan to gauge Mr. Collins's future wealth.
Expresses triumph over having a daughter well married

Kitty Bennet and Lydia Bennet.Action: Far from envying Miss Lucas, unaffected by the news other than as gossip.

Kitty and Lydia Bennet.Action: Dismiss Mr. Collins because he is only a clergyman

Mr. Gardiner.Action: Listens to Mrs. Bennet's grievances with patience, implicitly showing sympathy.
Encourages Mrs. Reynolds' communicativeness and praises Mr. Darcy.
Expresses skepticism about Mr. Darcy's character, but acknowledges his politeness and unassuming behavior.
Expressing perfect willingness to accept Miss Darcy's invitation to dinner.
Shows willingness to socialize across varied groups.
Promises assistance in locating Lydia despite the shock of the situation.
Offers to help recover Lydia after her elopement.
Actively assists his brother-in-law in pursuing inquiries to resolve the distressing situation.
Takes charge of the search for Lydia and Wickham.
Generously offers financial assistance and personal protection to Lydia despite her elopement and social disgrace.
Expresses eagerness to promote the welfare of Mr. Bennet's family.
Assists with paying off Wickham's debts and securing his future military position.
Supports his niece by helping with debts and seeking a better social position through the army

Mrs. Gardiner.Action: Listens to Mrs. Bennet's grievances and tries to shift the conversation to alleviate discomfort.
Eagerly engages Elizabeth in conversation to offer consolation and advice following Jane's disappointment.
Suspiciously observes Elizabeth and Mr. Wickham, indicating distrust.
Resolves to speak to Elizabeth about the imprudence of encouraging an attachment with Wickham.
Attempts to divert conversation for the comfort of her nieces.
Cautions Elizabeth against an imprudent affection due to the lack of fortune.
Cautions Elizabeth against involving herself with someone of inadequate fortune.
Expresses a desire to revisit a place of former residence.
Expresses wonder and pleasure at Mr. Darcy's civility which far exceeded expectations.
Acknowledges Mr. Darcy's pleasant demeanor despite his supposed pride.
Engages in social activities and accepts invitations from different social circles.
Carries on conversation to alleviate awkwardness.
Condemns Wickham's actions but remains hopeful and supports her niece.
Remains in Hertfordshire to support her nieces and provide comfort to them.

Miss Bennet.Action: Accepts her aunt's invitation with pleasure, indicating openness to change and support.

Charlotte.Action: Encourages her husband’s pleasure in gardening, showing support.

Lady Catherine de Bourgh.Action: Ensures her guests are transported home by her carriage.
Frequently invites Mr. Collins and his guests to dine at her estate and ensures their transportation.
Entered the room with an ungracious air and made no reply to Elizabeth's salutation except a slight inclination of the head.
Presented herself with the determined resolution to carry her purpose, disregarding Elizabeth's feelings and opinions.
Insisted on knowing Elizabeth's private affairs and tried to dictate her actions.
Asserts the superiority of her family lineage and insists on maintaining class distinctions by preventing a marriage.
Attempted to convince Elizabeth to refuse Darcy's proposal to uphold social hierarchy and family expectations.

Miss De Bourgh.Action: Kept Charlotte waiting outside in the wind.
Rarely comes inside when visiting and is seen as doing a great favor when she does.

Maria Lucas.Action: Is apprehensive and frightened at the introduction to Lady Catherine.

Lady Catherine.Action: Asks numerous personal questions of Elizabeth in an impertinent manner.
Maintains a strict sense of rank and displays authoritative behavior, making her visitors aware of their inferior position.
Actively oversees and intervenes in the minutest concerns of the parish.
Civilly receiving the visitors but focusing more on her nephews.
Calling out instructions and criticisms regarding Elizabeth's music.
Giving instructions and criticisms about Elizabeth's music.
Speaks about superior music taste and proficiency without having learned.
Remarks about Elizabeth needing more practice and the advantage of a London master.
Mentions Anne would have been a delightful performer if her health allowed her.
Invited Elizabeth to stay longer and offered assistance for her journey.
Ensured young women travelled properly guarded.
Gave meticulous directions for packing and wished a good journey.
Takes trouble to break off Elizabeth's supposed engagement with Darcy.
Displayed indignation at Elizabeth's marriage to Darcy.

Mrs. Jenkinson.Action: Attends carefully to Miss de Bourgh's needs during dinner.

Sir William.Action: Feels awe due to the grandeur surrounding him and feels compelled to a very low bow.

Colonel Fitzwilliam.Action: Engages in conversation with readiness and ease without asserting social hierarchy.
Seating himself by Elizabeth and talking agreeably.
Drawing a chair near Elizabeth to listen to her playing.
Talks agreeably with Elizabeth and seats himself by her.
Frequently visited the Parsonage for the pleasure of their company.
Engaged in a friendly conversation with Elizabeth and shared details about Mr. Darcy’s interference in a friend's imprudent marriage.
Admits dependence on wealth for marital choices.
Being agreeable and not causing Elizabeth unhappiness.

Mrs. Collins.Action: Watched Mr. Darcy to find out if he was in love with Elizabeth.
Does not press Elizabeth to go to Rosings when she sees she is really unwell and tries to prevent her husband from pressing her.

Miss de Bourgh.Action: Courtesied and held out her hand to both Elizabeth and Maria.

Mrs. Reynolds.Action: Speaks highly of Mr. Darcy, emphasizing his good nature and generosity.
Describes Mr. Darcy as affable to the poor and highly praises his character.

Miss Darcy.Action: Expressing wish to see Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner, and Miss Bennet to dinner at Pemberley.
Displays diffidence, marking little habit of giving invitations.
Shows embarrassment and shyness, indicative of fear of doing wrong.
Shows embarrassment and avoids conversation due to shyness.

Georgiana Darcy.Action: Is unable to speak due to confusion but tries to join conversation.

Mrs. Annesley.Action: Initiates conversation and interaction amongst the group in a civil manner.

Wickham.Action: Refused initial reasonable terms of help and demanded more than he could get.
Continuously tried to manipulate and misrepresent past events concerning himself and Mr. Darcy.

A Young Lady.Action: Whispers to Elizabeth that they don't need the men to join them.

Mrs. Long.Action: Compliments Jane Bennet's beauty and suggests a positive future.

Miss Bennet (Jane).Action: Expresses satisfaction with the day and Bingley's behavior.

Unspecified Lady.Action: Declares determination to avoid interaction with men at the party.

Mr. Bingley and Jane.Action: Moved away from their lower-status relatives.

Kitty.Action: Improved herself by spending time with her higher-status sisters.

Elizabeth Bennet and Mr. Darcy.Action: Maintained intimate and grateful terms with the Gardiners, who were of lower social status.
